New report reveals shocking number of excess deaths caused by crowding in Emergency Depts. last year

A new RCEM report ‘Crowding + its Consequences’ has found that at least 4,519 patients have died as a result of crowding +12 hr stays in Emergency Depts. in England in 2020-2021.

📖🚨READ THE FULL REPORT HERE:

It is unacceptable that people are dying due to crowding in EDs. Patient safety must come first. We urge @sajidjavid to meet us to discuss these findings & ensure the UEC system is adequately resourced to meet demand.
💰 More funding is required for social care. We know the lack of integration between the NHS and social care leads to delayed discharges for many patients.

Our members have told us that fixing operational pressures by improving flow & eliminating exit block would improve their wellbeing at work. Getting rid of crowding, through increasing capacity, would support the retention of our current workforce.

👩‍⚕‍👨‍⚕‍There is a shortage of 2000-2500 Emergency Medicine Consultants across the UK. 
 
This gap must be filled in order to achieve safe staffing. Unfortunately, the Comprehensive Spending Review did not provide certainty over HEE's budget.

🏥The NHS needs more hospital beds. 
 
As we've long argued, this is important for BOTH the emergency and elective recovery. A lack of beds is one of the top reasons for cancelled electives and exit block. 
 
We cannot have more beds without more staff🩺

There is an urgent need to act now to protect our patients. To eradicate crowding and address the problems facing the UEC system, last week we published RCEM CARES: The Next Phase. 

https://t.co/HLaEtO9PjW
What these figures do not show is the harm that those waiting even longer may have come to, and those who did not die but nonetheless came into other harm due to the delay they experienced.

By applying this data, in 2021 so far there have been 303 excess deaths in Scotland and 709 in Wales. Assuming that the harm suffered between 8-12 hours continues in patients who stay past 12 hours, then 4519 excess deaths occurred in England & 566 in Northern Ireland in 2020-21.

Crowding is dangerous for patients. Crowded EDs delay and dilute care, and this increases a patient’s risk of death after they have left the ED. The GIRFT report found that for every 67 patients that stay in the ED for 8-12 hours, there is one excess death.

🌡️Levels of burnout & moral distress are consistently reported as higher amongst EM physicians than other specialties. This can lead to increased attrition rates through mental & physical illness, changing career, retiring early, LTFT working, or adopting portfolio careers. https://t.co/7gl7zWGctX

ED staff working in crowded conditions experience a number of ill effects, including an increased risk of adverse events, potential violence and aggression towards staff, and a greater likelihood of stress and burnout. It also increases the risk of nosocomial infection.

💰EM is a leading source of litigation claims in the NHS, responsible for 11% of NHS liabilities. The annual cost of litigation equals 14% of the running costs of EM & in 2019/20 £382M was spent on clinical negligence claims. The impact of crowding can contribute to this.

📈 Alongside the loss of beds, occupancy rates have risen. Occupancy should stay below 85% to ensure flow but quarterly bed data shows that it has never been below this figure until the pandemic. In Q1 2021/22, occupancy stood at 85.4%, posing a worry for this coming winter.

🛏️Bed availability is dependent on the number of physical beds, staffing levels in the hospital, and the efficiency of the discharge process. Between 2010/11 & 2021/22, there was a loss of 13,570 G&A overnight beds in the NHS, with 5196 lost during the pandemic. https://t.co/PMiEkcKSux

🛏️Crowding is directly related to bed capacity in the hospital system. When there are fewer beds available on wards, it is difficult or even impossible to admit patients. Patients therefore remain in the ED until a bed is available for them, often waiting on trolleys.

🚑Patients waiting in ambulances also suffer harm. At least 2 patients are at risk for every ambulance unable to offload: the patient IN the ambulance & a further patient waiting FOR an ambulance. Recent @AACE_org report reveals alarming levels of harm endured by patients

When EDs become crowded, they can no longer accept patients who arrive by ambulance, and the ambulances containing these patients are forced to wait outside. The current national target for handovers is 1⃣ 5⃣ minutes - any waits beyond this are considered to be a delay. https://t.co/FiRpN7xBoT

⛔️ There is no clinical need for a patient to be in an ED for longer than 6 hours, showing that these long waits are a result of crowding. Same Day Emergency Care provision needs to be expanded to avoid unnecessary admissions and long waits.

⏱️Quality indicators show that patients are spending longer in the ED: in August 2021, the median length of time that all types of patients spent in the ED was 3 hrs, whilst the 95th centile stood at 11 hrs. For admitted patients this stood at 5 hrs and 15.8 hrs respectively https://t.co/1rEPFLym5I

🚑Ambulance handovers also provide an insight into crowding; the median handover time is currently 10 minutes, the highest on record, with 95% of handovers occurring within 97 minutes.

This is worse than the delays from winter 2019, one of the worst winters on record. https://t.co/H1z0K6lkmy

Crowding is a major threat to public health and has worsened due to the mismatch between capacity⬇️ and demand⬆️

19/19 Not only do hospitals and EDs need to be expanded to keep up with demand, but all parts of the healthcare system – including primary care, mental health, and community care – require additional capacity so patients can access the right kind of care at the right time.

18/19 Due to IPC measures and a decreased bed stock, EDs are less able to cope with this demand, resulting in unsafe conditions for patients. It is likely that demand will only increase as we move into the winter months which means action needs to be taken to ensure we can cope.

17/19 Whilst the increase in demand isn't directly related to covid cases, the indirect effect of the pandemic has led to more people turning to EDs for healthcare. This way of working isn't sustainable for the EM workforce and can lead to increased rates of burnout.

16/19 It is expected that these infections, and subsequently demand, will continue to rise as we enter the winter months due to diminishing population immunity, which will hit young children the hardest as they have not been exposed to these infections before.

15/19 Many parents are taking their young children with mild fevers to EDs rather than seeking help at GPs, pharmacies, or NHS 111 because they are worried about these symptoms that they have potentially not experienced in their child before.

14/19 One group that has disproportionately increased demand in EDs over recent months is children and young people. Due to easing lockdown restrictions, there are high numbers of young children acquiring infections that are usually seen in the winter months. https://t.co/Wdgk74XGvx

13/19 Alongside fewer patients being treated, 6 million fewer people were referred into consultant-led elective care in 2020 compared to 2019. It is likely that they are beginning to attend EDs with more serious, untreated issues, now that fear of covid has largely diminished.

12/19 The growth in the elective backlog over the past year has led to further demands in EDs. 5.3 million people are on the elective surgery waiting list and many are facing health complications as a result of their delayed surgery, meaning they are turning to EDs for care. https://t.co/NTghRuvK2Z

11/19 The purpose of NHS 111 is to give advice and make accessing healthcare services easier during times of urgency. Callers should be directed to the most appropriate service, limiting demand in EDs. However, this data shows that it is currently not fulfilling its purpose.

10/19 In our recent workforce survey, an overwhelming 50.7% responded that phone-first services had increased or significantly increased demand in their ED, while only 3.6% responded that it had decreased or significantly decreased demand.

9/19 As the graph shows, there's a noticeable increase in the percentage of calls recommended to EDs since the start of pandemic; prior to May 2020, this percentage almost always remained under 10% and translates to almost 100,000 more recommendations between April 2020 and 2021 https://t.co/y2MsPPzRK1

8/19 There's also been an increase in the number of NHS 111 calls over recent months, and in particular, the percentage of callers streamed towards EDs. In June 2021, 12.3% of triaged callers were recommended to attend EDs and 11.5% of triaged calls led to ambulance dispatches.

7/19 Therefore, some EDs have been functioning as a ‘first contact’ for people in mental health crisis due to a lack of alternatives, placing greater pressure on the system but also potentially causing greater stress for those patients presenting.

6/19 There's an increase in the number of people with mental illnesses, due to isolation and anxiety caused by multiple lockdowns, partnered with this difficulty in accessing mental health services. Many people can't access support until their conditions have worsened.

5/19 Similarly, access to mental health services has become even more difficult. Many mental health services went virtual at the beginning of the pandemic - these are not always appropriate and can act as a barrier to services, particularly for the more seriously ill patients. https://t.co/i6AAW7a8sB

4/19 Maintaining the balance between virtual & in-person helps people to access healthcare when/how they want. Demand for GPs has increased due to covid vaccine rollout & workforce challenges. Small changes in the number of people accessing GPs could put great pressure on EDs https://t.co/ah4gvz3NkZ

3/19 The first factor that has increased demand is the lack of access to other healthcare services. Since the first lockdown, most primary care services have become virtual, making it easier for some to access healthcare but potentially at the risk of excluding other groups. https://t.co/lovFaJF6xH

2/19 ED attendances are surpassing pre-pandemic levels: June 2021 saw the highest number of attendances on record, yet covid hospitalisations are remaining fairly low, which raises the question – why are we experiencing winter pressures during the spring and summer months?

Thanks for reading all! To find more information about the new 111 system from @RCollEM and @HealthwatchE head to the RCEM website or click this link to get the full FAQs: https://t.co/u0nsPfyUyl

It is important that patients do not attend A&E if they are seeking a test or have covid-19 symptoms, unless they are having severe difficulty breathing. This is to ensure covid-19 is not spread. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

What should I do if I think I have Covid-19? If you have symptoms of Covid-19 you should call 111 to be assessed. You can also call 119 to find out where your nearest testing centre is. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Can I wait in A&E if I want to? If you have been referred to another service, it is recommended you go there. If you go to A&E with a less serious problem, you will be seen and treated but may have to wait a lot longer. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Are A&E appointments first come first serve? Patients are always assessed and prioritised based on the urgency of their need, meaning those who need emergency or urgent care will be treated as a priority. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Where I might go if I don’t go to A&E? Patients calling 111 may be given an A&E appointment, a referral to a GP, directed to a local pharmacist, or given expert advice for self-care and treatment. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE
The simple idea is that those with less urgent care needs will call 111 where they will receive an assessment and be directed to an appropriate and effective service. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE
Will I be turned away from A&E? Our patients and their care are our top priority, meaning we will never turn away anyone experiencing a medical emergency and seeking care. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Having an appointment at A&E means patients will not have to wait as they will be seen at their allotted time, avoiding queues and the risk of contracting covid-19 in a crowded department. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE
What is an appointment at A&E? An appointment at A&E is for non-life-threatening conditions and patients will be given an allotted appointment time to attend A&E. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE
Importantly, if you call 111 you will always speak to a trained professional who will either be a healthcare clinician or be able to get input from one. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

How can 111 help me? Advisers on 111 will be able to provide expert health advice and assess your condition. They may book you an appointment at A&E if needed, where your non-life-threatening emergency will be treated at an allotted time. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

What is a non-emergency? A non-life-threatening emergency would include things like sprained ankles or wrists, earaches, migraines. In such situations we urge you to call 111 to access the right care or for advice. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

What if I have a medical emergency? You should call 999 or attend A&E immediately if you have a life-threatening situation or condition, such as: head trauma, loss of consciousness, severe bleeding or burns, breathing difficulties, chest pain. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE
So, we’re asking patients with non-life-threatening emergencies to call 111 before attending A&E. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

We want to reduce the chances of Covid being spread in healthcare settings. While A&Es are safe, the more crowded they get, there is a higher potential risk of patients unwittingly infecting others. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Each and every patient is important to us and we want anyone seeking medical care to be treated quickly and effectively and we think some patients will receive more appropriate care via alternative services, such as their local GP. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Why are these changes being made? In Emergency Medicine our priority is to help those in a potentially life-threatening condition for whom emergency and urgent care could save their lives. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

A new system is being introduced for the way patients access urgent and emergency care to reduce risk of covid-19 infection, to ensure patients are safe and can access the right care. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE

Covid-19 has affected all of us and the way we live our lives. For the health service it has shown that we need to make changes to how people access care to help safeguard our patients. #NHS111 @HealthwatchE
